t: Job 1
Job’s Character and Wealth
There*p was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job; and that man was blameless, upright, fearing God and turning away from evil.
Seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
His possessions also were 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 female donkeys, and very many servants; and that man was the greatest of all the men of the east.
His sons used to go and hold a feast in the house of each one on his day, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

When the days of feasting had completed their cycle, Job would send and consecrate them, rising up early in the morning and offering burnt offerings according*i to*i the number of them all; for Job said, “Perhaps my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did continually.
Now*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came among them.
The Lord*s said to Satan, “From where do you come?” Then Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “From roaming about on the earth and walking around on it.”
The Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job? For there is no one like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, fearing God and turning away from evil.”
Then Satan answered the Lord,*s “Does Job fear God for nothing?
Have You not made a hedge about him and his house and all that he has, on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
But put forth Your hand now and touch all that he has; he will surely curse You to Your face.”
Then the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your power, only do not put forth your hand on him.” So Satan departed from the presence of the Lord.*s
Satan Allowed to Test Job
Now*p on the day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,
and the Sabeans attacked and took them. They also slew the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants and consumed them, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”

While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three bands and made a raid on the camels and took them and slew the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
While he was still speaking, another also came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
and behold, a great wind came from across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people and they died, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
Then*p Job arose and tore his robe and shaved his head, and he fell to the ground and worshiped.
He said, “Naked*pn I came from my mother’s womb, And*ln naked I shall return there. The*ln Lord*s gave and the Lord*s has taken away. Blessed*ln be the name of the Lord.”*s
Through*p all this Job did not sin nor did he blame God.
Job 2
Job Loses His Health
Again*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came among them to present himself before the Lord.*s
The Lord*s said to Satan, “Where have you come from?” Then Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “From roaming about on the earth and walking around on it.”

The Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job? For there is no one like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man fearing God and turning away from evil. And he still holds fast his integrity, although you incited Me against him to ruin him without cause.”
Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “Skin for skin! Yes, all that a man has he will give for his life.
However, put forth Your hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh; he will curse You to Your face.”
So the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your power, only spare his life.”
Then*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord*s and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
And he took a potsherd to scrape himself while he was sitting among the ashes.
Then*p his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast your integrity? Curse God and die!”
But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women speaks. Shall we indeed accept good from God and not accept adversity?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.

Now*p when Job’s three friends heard of all this adversity that had come upon him, they came each one from his own place, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite; and they made an appointment together to come to sympathize with him and comfort him.
When they lifted up their eyes at a distance and did not recognize him, they raised their voices and wept. And each of them tore his robe and they threw dust over their heads toward the sky.
Then they sat down on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights with no one speaking a word to him, for they saw that his*i pain was very great.
Job 3
Job’s Lament
Afterward*p Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.*i
And Job said,
“Let*pn the day perish on which I was to be born, And*ln the night which*i said, ‘A boy is conceived.’
May*ln that day be darkness; Let*ln not God above care for it, Nor*ln light shine on it.
Let*ln darkness and black gloom claim it; Let*ln a cloud settle on it; Let*ln the blackness of the day terrify it.
As*iln for*i that night, let darkness seize it; Let*ln it not rejoice among the days of the year; Let*ln it not come into the number of the months.
Behold,*ln let that night be barren; Let*ln no joyful shout enter it.
Let*ln those curse it who curse the day, Who*ln are prepared to rouse Leviathan.
Let*ln the stars of its twilight be darkened; Let*ln it wait for light but have none, And*ln let it not see the breaking dawn;
Because*ln it did not shut the opening of my mother’s*i womb, Or*ln hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*ln did I not die at birth, Come*ln forth from the womb and expire?
Why*ln did the knees receive me, And*ln why the breasts, that I should suck?
For*ln now I would have lain down and been quiet; I*ln would have slept then, I would have been at rest,
With*ln kings and with*i counselors of the earth, Who*ln rebuilt ruins for themselves;
Or*ln with princes who had gold, Who*ln were filling their houses with*i silver.
Or*ln like a miscarriage which is discarded, I would not be, As*ln infants that never saw light.
There*ln the wicked cease from raging, And*ln there the weary are at rest.
The*ln prisoners are at ease together; They*ln do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
The*ln small and the great are there, And*ln the slave is free from his master.
“Why*ln is light given to him who suffers, And*ln life to the bitter of soul,
Who*ln long for death, but there is none, And*ln dig for it more than for hidden treasures,
Who*ln rejoice greatly, And*iln exult when they find the grave?
Why*iln is*i light*i given*i to a man whose way is hidden, And*ln whom God has hedged in?
For*ln my groaning comes at the sight of my food, And*ln my cries pour out like water.
For*ln what I fear comes upon me, And*ln what I dread befalls me.
I*ln am not at ease, nor am I quiet, And*ln I am not at rest, but turmoil comes.”
Job 4
Eliphaz: Innocent Do Not Suffer
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered,
“If*pn one ventures a word with you, will you become impatient? But*ln who can refrain from speaking?
Behold*ln you have admonished many, And*ln you have strengthened weak hands.
Your*ln words have helped the tottering to stand, And*ln you have strengthened feeble knees.
But*ln now it has come to you, and you are impatient; It*ln touches you, and you are dismayed.
Is*ln not your fear of*i God*i your confidence, And*ln the integrity of your ways your hope?
“Remember*ln now, who ever*i perished being innocent? Or*ln where were the upright destroyed?
According*ln to what I have seen, those who plow iniquity And*ln those who sow trouble harvest it.
By*ln the breath of God they perish, And*ln by the blast of His anger they come to an end.
The*ln roaring of the lion and the voice of the fierce*i lion, And*ln the teeth of the young lions are broken.
The*ln lion perishes for lack of prey, And*ln the whelps of the lioness are scattered.
“Now*ln a word was brought to me stealthily, And*ln my ear received a whisper of it.
Amid*ln disquieting thoughts from the visions of the night, When*ln deep sleep falls on men,
Dread*ln came upon me, and trembling, And*ln made all my bones shake.
Then*ln a spirit passed by my face; The*ln hair of my flesh bristled up.
It*ln stood still, but I could not discern its appearance; A*ln form was*i before my eyes; There*iln was*i silence, then I heard a voice:
‘Can*ln mankind be just before God? Can*ln a man be pure before his Maker?
He*ln puts no trust even in His servants; And*ln against His angels He charges error.
How*ln much more those who dwell in houses of clay, Whose*ln foundation is in the dust, Who*ln are crushed before the moth!
Between*ln morning and evening they are broken in pieces; Unobserved,*ln they perish forever.
Is*ln not their tent-cord plucked up within them? They*ln die, yet without wisdom.’
Job 5
God Is Just
“Call*pn now, is there anyone who will answer you? And*ln to which of the holy ones will you turn?
For*ln anger slays the foolish man, And*ln jealousy kills the simple.
I*ln have seen the foolish taking root, And*ln I cursed his abode immediately.
His*ln sons are far from safety, They*ln are even oppressed in the gate, And*ln there is no deliverer.
His*ln harvest the hungry devour And*ln take it to a place*i of*i thorns, And*ln the schemer is eager for their wealth.
For*ln affliction does not come from the dust, Nor*ln does trouble sprout from the ground,
For*ln man is born for trouble, As*ln sparks fly upward.
“But*ln as for me, I would seek God, And*ln I would place my cause before God;
Who*ln does great and unsearchable things, Wonders*ln without number.
He*ln gives rain on the earth And*ln sends water on the fields,
So*ln that He sets on high those who are lowly, And*ln those who mourn are lifted to safety.
He*ln frustrates the plotting of the shrewd, So*ln that their hands cannot attain success.
He*ln captures the wise by their own shrewdness, And*ln the advice of the cunning is quickly thwarted.
By*ln day they meet with darkness, And*ln grope at noon as in the night.
But*ln He saves from the sword of their mouth, And*ln the poor from the hand of the mighty.
So*ln the helpless has hope, And*ln unrighteousness must shut its mouth.
“Behold,*ln how happy is the man whom God reproves, So*ln do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
For*ln He inflicts pain, and gives relief; He*ln wounds, and His hands also*i heal.
From*ln six troubles He will deliver you, Even*ln in seven evil will not touch you.
In*ln famine He will redeem you from death, And*ln in war from the power of the sword.
You*ln will be hidden from the scourge of the tongue, And*ln you will not be afraid of violence when it comes.
You*ln will laugh at violence and famine, And*ln you will not be afraid of wild beasts.
For*ln you will be in league with the stones of the field, And*ln the beasts of the field will be at peace with you.
You*ln will know that your tent is secure, For*ln you will visit your abode and fear no loss.
You*ln will know also that your descendants will be many, And*ln your offspring as the grass of the earth.
You*ln will come to the grave in full vigor, Like*ln the stacking of grain in its season.
Behold*ln this; we have investigated it, and*i so it is. Hear*ln it, and know for yourself.”
Job 6
Job’s Friends Are No Help
Then*p Job answered,
“Oh*pn that my grief were actually weighed And*ln laid in the balances together with my calamity!
For*ln then it would be heavier than the sand of the seas; Therefore*ln my words have been rash.
For*ln the arrows of the Almighty are within me, Their*ln poison my spirit drinks; The*ln terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does*ln the wild donkey bray over his*i grass, Or*ln does the ox low over his fodder?
Can*ln something tasteless be eaten without salt, Or*ln is there any taste in the white of an egg?
My*ln soul refuses to touch them;*i They*ln are like loathsome food to me.
“Oh*ln that my request might come to pass, And*ln that God would grant my longing!
Would*ln that God were willing to crush me, That*ln He would loose His hand and cut me off!
But*ln it is still my consolation, And*ln I rejoice in unsparing pain, That*ln I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
What*ln is my strength, that I should wait? And*ln what is my end, that I should endure?
Is*ln my strength the strength of stones, Or*ln is my flesh bronze?
Is*ln it that my help is not within me, And*ln that deliverance is driven from me?
“For*ln the despairing man there*i should*i be*i kindness from his friend; So*ln that he does not forsake the fear of the Almighty.
My*ln brothers have acted deceitfully like a wadi, Like*ln the torrents of wadis which vanish,
Which*ln are turbid because of ice And*iln into which the snow melts.
When*ln they become waterless, they are silent, When*ln it is hot, they vanish from their place.
The*ln paths of their course wind along, They*ln go up into nothing and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema looked, The*ln travelers of Sheba hoped for them.
They*ln were disappointed for they had trusted, They*ln came there and were confounded.
Indeed,*ln you have now become such, You*ln see a terror and are afraid.
Have*ln I said, ‘Give me something,’*i Or,*ln ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth,’
Or,*ln ‘Deliver me from the hand of the adversary,’ Or,*ln ‘Redeem me from the hand of the tyrants’?
“Teach*ln me, and I will be silent; And*ln show me how I have erred.
How*ln painful are honest words! But*ln what does your argument prove?
Do*ln you intend to reprove my*i words, When*ln the words of one in despair belong to the wind?
You*ln would even cast lots*i for the orphans And*ln barter over your friend.
Now*ln please look at me, And*ln see*i if I lie to your face.
Desist*ln now, let there be no injustice; Even*ln desist, my righteousness is yet in it.
Is*ln there injustice on my tongue? Cannot*ln my palate discern calamities?
Job 7
Job’s Life Seems Futile
“Is*pn not man forced to labor on earth, And*ln are*i not*i his days like the days of a hired man?
As*ln a slave who pants for the shade, And*ln as a hired man who eagerly waits for his wages,
So*ln am I allotted months of vanity, And*ln nights of trouble are appointed me.
When*ln I lie down I say, ‘When*ln shall I arise?’ But*ln the night continues, And*ln I am continually tossing until dawn.
My*ln flesh is clothed with worms and a crust of dirt, My*ln skin hardens and runs.
My*ln days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, And*ln come to an end without hope.
“Remember*ln that my life is but*i breath; My*ln eye will not again see good.
The*ln eye of him who sees me will behold me no longer; Your*ln eyes will*i be*i on me, but I will not be.
When*ln a cloud vanishes, it is gone, So*ln he who goes down to Sheol does not come up.
He*ln will not return again to his house, Nor*ln will his place know him anymore.
“Therefore*ln I will not restrain my mouth; I*ln will speak in the anguish of my spirit, I*ln will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ln I the sea, or the sea monster, That*ln You set a guard over me?
If*ln I say, ‘My bed will comfort me, My*ln couch will ease my complaint,’
Then*ln You frighten me with dreams And*ln terrify me by visions;
So*ln that my soul would choose suffocation, Death*ln rather than my pains.
I*ln waste away; I will not live forever. Leave*ln me alone, for my days are but*i a breath.
What*ln is man that You magnify him, And*ln that You are concerned about him,
That*ln You examine him every morning And*ln try him every moment?
Will*ln You never turn Your gaze away from me, Nor*ln let me alone until I swallow my spittle?
Have*ln I sinned? What have I done to You, O*ln watcher of men? Why*ln have You set me as Your target, So*ln that I am a burden to myself?
Why*ln then do You not pardon my transgression And*ln take away my iniquity? For*ln now I will lie down in the dust; And*ln You will seek me, but I will not be.”
Job 8
Bildad Says God Rewards the Good
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite answered,
“How*pn long will you say these things, And*ln the words of your mouth be a mighty wind?
Does*ln God pervert justice? Or*ln does the Almighty pervert what is right?
If*ln your sons sinned against Him, Then*ln He delivered them into the power of their transgression.
If*ln you would seek God And*ln implore the compassion of the Almighty,
If*ln you are pure and upright, Surely*ln now He would rouse Himself for you And*ln restore your righteous estate.
Though*ln your beginning was insignificant, Yet*ln your end will increase greatly.
“Please*ln inquire of past generations, And*ln consider the things searched out by their fathers.
For*ln we are only*i of yesterday and know nothing, Because*ln our days on earth are as a shadow.
Will*ln they not teach you and*i tell you, And*ln bring forth words from their minds?

While*ln it is still green and*i not cut down, Yet*ln it withers before any other*i plant.
So*ln are the paths of all who forget God; And*ln the hope of the godless will perish,
Whose*ln confidence is fragile, And*ln whose trust a spider’s web.
He*ln trusts in his house, but it does not stand; He*ln holds fast to it, but it does not endure.
He*ln thrives before the sun, And*ln his shoots spread out over his garden.
His*ln roots wrap around a rock pile, He*ln grasps a house of stones.
If*ln he is removed from his place, Then*ln it will deny him, saying,*i ‘I never saw you.’

Lo,*ln God will not reject a*i man*i of*i integrity, Nor*ln will He support the evildoers.

Job 9
Job Says There Is No Arbitrator between God and Man
Then*p Job answered,
“In*pn truth I know that this is so; But*ln how can a man be in the right before God?
If*ln one wished to dispute with Him, He*ln could not answer Him once in a thousand times.*i
Wise*ln in heart and mighty in strength, Who*ln has defied Him without harm?
It*iln is*i God*i who removes the mountains, they know not how,*i When*ln He overturns them in His anger;
Who*ln shakes the earth out of its place, And*ln its pillars tremble;

Who*ln does great things, unfathomable, And*ln wondrous works without number.
Were*ln He to pass by me, I would not see Him; Were*ln He to move past me,*i I would not perceive Him.
Were*ln He to snatch away, who could restrain Him? Who*ln could say to Him, ‘What are You doing?’

How*ln then can I answer Him, And*iln choose my words before Him?
For*ln though I were right, I could not answer; I*ln would have to implore the mercy of my judge.
If*ln I called and He answered me, I*ln could not believe that He was listening to my voice.

I*ln am guiltless; I*ln do not take notice of myself; I*ln despise my life.

The*ln earth is given into the hand of the wicked; He*ln covers the faces of its judges. If*ln it*i is*i not He,*i then who is it?

They*ln slip by like reed boats, Like*ln an eagle that swoops on its prey.
Though*ln I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ln will leave off my sad*i countenance and be cheerful,’
I*ln am afraid of all my pains, I*ln know that You will not acquit me.

Yet*ln You would plunge me into the pit, And*ln my own clothes would abhor me.
For*ln He*i is*i not a man as I am that I may answer Him, That*ln we may go to court together.

Job 10
Job Despairs of God’s Dealings
“I*pn loathe my own life; I*ln will give full vent to my complaint; I*ln will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln will say to God, ‘Do not condemn me; Let*ln me know why You contend with me.

That*ln You should seek for my guilt And*ln search after my sin?

Did*ln You not pour me out like milk And*ln curdle me like cheese;

Would*ln He not let my few days alone? Withdraw*ln from me that I may have a little cheer
Before*ln I go—and I shall not return— To*ln the land of darkness and deep shadow,

Job 11
Zophar Rebukes Job

Job 12
Job Chides His Accusers
Then*p Job responded,
“Truly*pn then you are the people, And*ln with you wisdom will die!
But*ln I have intelligence as well as you; I*ln am not inferior to you. And*ln who does not know such things as these?

Job Speaks of the Power of God

Job 13
Job Says His Friends’ Proverbs Are Ashes
“Behold,*pn my eye has seen all this,*i My*ln ear has heard and understood it.
